Paper 1.stem: Below is a graph from the Annual Climate Singapore 2023, which shows the top 10 warmest years in Singapore since 1929.
Paper 1.diagramDescription: Bar graph titled 'Top 10 Warmest Years' showing temperature (in °C) on the y-axis (from 27.8 to 28.5) and years on the x-axis (2019, 2016, 1998, 2023, 2015, 1997, 2010, 2002, 2020, 2005). The bar for 2023 is labelled $28.2^{\circ}C$ and a text box indicates '2023 is the 4th warmest year since 1929'.

diagram.description: Bar graph titled 'Top 10 Warmest Years' showing temperature (in °C) on the y-axis (from 27.8 to 28.5) and years on the x-axis (2019, 2016, 1998, 2023, 2015, 1997, 2010, 2002, 2020, 2005).
diagram.notes: Bar graph required - tool not available

parts.questionText: State one aspect of the graph that may be misleading and explain how this may lead to a misinterpretation of the graph.

solution.finalAnswer: The y-axis starts at 27.8°C instead of 0°C, which exaggerates the visual differences between the temperatures and may make the temperature variations appear more dramatic than they actually are.

stepByStep.working: The y-axis does not start at zero; it starts at 27.8°C. This truncated scale makes the bars appear much taller relative to each other than they would be if the full scale from 0°C was used
stepByStep.reasoning: When a graph's y-axis doesn't start at zero, it can visually exaggerate differences between values

stepByStep.working: A reader might perceive that 2019 was significantly hotter than 2005 because the bar for 2019 appears roughly 3-4 times taller than the bar for 2005. However, the actual temperature difference is only $28.4 - 28.1 = 0.3^{\circ}C$, which is relatively small. The truncated y-axis makes this small difference look much larger visually, potentially leading viewers to overestimate the magnitude of climate change or temperature variations
stepByStep.reasoning: The visual representation suggests a larger proportional difference than the actual numerical difference, which can mislead viewers about the severity or significance of temperature changes

Paper 1.title: Data Misrepresentation

Paper 1.stem: The cumulative frequency diagram shows the time in hours that 80 students spent on a project.
Paper 1.diagramDescription: A cumulative frequency curve with Time (hours) on the x-axis (scale 0 to 10) and Cumulative Frequency on the y-axis (scale 0 to 80). The curve starts at (0,0), passes through (2,6), (4,24), (6,60), (8,76), and ends at (10,80).

diagram.description: Cumulative frequency curve for 80 students. X-axis: 0-10 hours. Y-axis: 0-80 students.
diagram.notes: Ensure x-axis labels are 0, 1, 2...10. Ensure y-axis major gridlines allow easy reading of 60.

parts.questionText: Explain whether you can find the exact number of students who spent exactly 5 hours on the project.

solution.finalAnswer: No, it is not possible to find the exact number of students who spent exactly 5 hours.

stepByStep.explanation: Identify the limitation of Cumulative Frequency graphs.
stepByStep.working: The cumulative frequency diagram plots the number of students who spent 'less than or equal to' a certain time. It represents grouped continuous data.
stepByStep.reasoning: The graph shows accumulated totals ($x \leq t$), not individual frequencies for specific exact values.

parts.questionText: The teacher notes that 75% of the students spent less than $k$ hours on the project. Find the value of $k$.

stepByStep.explanation: Calculate the cumulative frequency corresponding to 75%.
stepByStep.reasoning: We need to find the time $k$ where the cumulative frequency is 60.

stepByStep.explanation: Read the value from the graph.
stepByStep.working: Locate 60 on the vertical axis (Cumulative Frequency). Move horizontally to the curve, then vertically down to the x-axis. The line meets the x-axis at 6.
stepByStep.reasoning: Reading from the graph at $y = 60$, we find $x = 6$.

Paper 1.title: Data Plot Probability

Paper 1.stem: The box-and-whisker plot shows the distribution of masses, in kg, of 80 suitcases checked in at an airport.
Paper 1.diagramDescription: A box-and-whisker plot above a horizontal axis labeled 'Mass (kg)'. The axis ranges from 0 to 40. The plot has the following coordinates: Left whisker end at 6, left side of box at 12, vertical line inside box at 19, right side of box at 24, and right whisker end at 29.

diagram.description: Box-and-whisker plot. X-axis: 0-40 kg. Key values: Min=6, Q1=12, Med=19, Q3=24, Max=29.
diagram.notes: Ensure x-axis has major gridlines every 5 units and minor ticks every 1 unit. Label axis 'Mass (kg)'.

parts.questionText: Write down the median mass of the suitcases.

stepByStep.explanation: Identify the median on the plot.
stepByStep.working: Locate the vertical line inside the rectangular box.
stepByStep.reasoning: In a box-and-whisker plot, the line dividing the box represents the median value.

stepByStep.explanation: Read the value from the scale.
stepByStep.working: The line aligns with 19 on the x-axis.

parts.questionText: Calculate the interquartile range (IQR) of the masses.

stepByStep.explanation: Identify the Upper and Lower Quartiles.
stepByStep.working:
Lower Quartile ($Q_1$) = left edge of the box = 12.
Upper Quartile ($Q_3$) = right edge of the box = 24.
stepByStep.reasoning: The ends of the rectangular box represent the interquartile range boundaries.
The interquartile range is the difference between the upper and lower quartiles.

parts.questionText: Suitcases weighing more than 24 kg are tagged as 'Heavy'. Calculate the percentage of suitcases that are tagged as Heavy.

stepByStep.explanation: Identify the position of 24 kg relative to the quartiles.
stepByStep.working: 24 kg corresponds to the Upper Quartile ($Q_3$).
stepByStep.reasoning: The Upper Quartile marks the boundary where 75% of data is below and 25% is above.

stepByStep.working: The right whisker represents the top 25% of the data.
stepByStep.reasoning: Since 'Heavy' is $> Q_3$, exactly 25% of the suitcases are heavy.

Paper 1.title: Box Plot Interpretation
